 My response would be that pro-gunners are also guilty of sacrificing freedoms for security. Several of the 'inalienable rights' enumerated in the Constitution are waived under various circumstances - the Patriot act and (not for long) Gitmo are more extreme examples, but there are the everyday/accepted lapses such as a ban on paedophillia and shouting 'fire' in a movie theatre, or preventing felons from owning guns. The only difference between the two sides (pro-guns vs pro-control) is that they draw the line at different points - just because pro-control favours slightly more security does not mean that they want totalitarianism, just as pro-gunners do not want anarchy just because they favour slightly more freedom (the pro-gun 'criminals don't obey laws so laws are pointless' argument notwithstanding).
 
 The question then becomes, 'where do you draw the line between freedom and security'?
 
 My response to this question - and my rationale for drawing it where I do - is that the factor we should be aiming to maximise is not freedom or security, but 'quality of life for the population as a whole', which both freedom and security contribute to. This explains why you can't shout 'fire' in a movie theatre, just as it explains why (almost) everyone should be free from padded cells and gruel - because if either of those were to occur, the quality of life of the population as a whole would decrease. 
 
 This explains, also, why I don't particularly care about increaced CCTV in public spaces - given that it doesn't affect me unless I am breaking the law or being victimised, why should I care about being on camera in my public life?
